awd_titl_txt: Distortion-Tolerant Communications for  Ultra-Low Power Wireless Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Distortion-Tolerant Communication for Ultra-Low Power Wireless Networks
PI: Jingxian Wu, Proposal No. 1202075
Abstract
Intellectual Merit: Ultra-low power consumption is one of the most formidable challenges faced by the next generation wireless sensing systems, which are expected to operate uninterrupted over years or decades under extremely limited battery capacity or small energy scavenging devices. The goal of this research project is to advance the knowledge of ultra-low power wireless networks with a new paradigm of distortion-tolerant communication, which deliberately allows controlled distortion in a system. If we accept the fact that distortion is inevitable in practical communication systems, why not directly design a system that is naturally tolerant to distortion? Allowing instead of minimizing distortion, the proposed distortion-tolerant communication can operate in rate regions beyond the constraints imposed by Shannon channel capacity, the ultimate limit of distortion-free communications, thus achieving significant power reduction unrivaled by conventional technologies. The research approach is to systematically construct the theories, design tools, enabling technologies, and prototypes of ultra-low power distortion-tolerant wireless networks, which can be used for applications such as long-term structure health monitoring, biomedical sensing, and other wireless monitoring systems. The distortion-tolerant communication design approach is radically different from the error-minimization, throughput-maximization, and/or latency-minimization design criteria that dominate the current communication research. The new theories and technologies are developed by exploiting the unique features of wireless monitoring systems, such as delay-tolerance, distortion-tolerance, low data rate, and spatial data correlation, which provide extra degrees of freedom in the network design. The distortion-tolerant communication will enable innovative theories and technologies that are capable of coping with the unique challenges and opportunities arising from ultra-low power communications.
 
Broader Impacts: The outcomes of the proposed research and education activities will accelerate the wide range deployment of ultra-low power wireless networks for environmental and structure monitoring, surveillance, and biomedical sensing, which can provide early warning to prevent catastrophic results, improve public safety and homeland security, and promote the health and well-being of the general public. Outreach activities, such as annual visits to high schools and minority institutions for interactive project demonstrations, will attract more underrepresented students to pursue a career path in science and engineering.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this research project is to advance the knowledge of ultra-low power wireless networks with a new paradigm of distortion-tolerant communications. Outcomes of this project include new theories, design tools, and enabling technologies for ultra-low power distortion tolerant wireless networks. The new theories and technologies are developed by exploiting the unique features of wireless monitoring systems, such as delay-tolerance, distortion-tolerance, low data rate, and spatial data correlation, which provide extra degrees of freedom in the transceiver design. Some of the key outcomes of this project are summarized as follows.

  1. New distortion-tolerant sensing and communication schemes are developed for wireless sensor networks powered by energy harvesting devices. Many wireless sensing applications, such as structure health monitoring and environment monitoring, are expected to operate over a long period of time without changing battery. This necessitates the design of sensing systems powered by energy harvesting devices, which can harvest energy from the ambient environment. However, energy collected by energy harvesting devices are random, and they cannot guarantee energy availability when needed. Several new sensing schemes, such as best-effort uniform sensing, best-effort Poisson sensing, and active sparse sensing, have been developed to ensure that information can be reliably and efficiently collected by the wireless sensing network even with unreliable energy harvesting sources.
  2. A set of new distortion tolerant communication protocols are developed for dense wireless networks with strong mutual interference among users. Mutual interference among wireless devices increases signal distortions, and it is one of the main performance limiting factors in dense wireless networks. New communication protocols, such as collision-tolerant media access control, cyclic-shift multiple access, and random multiple access, are developed to manage and reduce the impacts of interference. These protocols can significantly improve the energy efficiency and spectrum utilization for distortion-tolerant dense wireless networks.
  3. New theories and technologies have been developed for high mobility distortion-tolerant wireless communication systems. In high mobility systems, it is difficult to accurately estimate and track the fast-changing wireless propagation environment, thus distortions in channel state estimation is inevitable. The fundamental performance limits of high mobility systems are analytically identified by studying the properties of channel estimation errors. New high mobility communication transceiver structures, such as Doppler diversity transmission, are developed under the guideline of the new theories. The new technologies can be applied to applications such as high speed railway communications and aircraft communications, etc.

Distortion-tolerant communication technologies developed in this project can significantly reduce the power consumption of communication devices, enable wireless communications with unreliable energy harvesting sources, and improve the utilization efficiency of the scarce spectrum resources. The outcomes of the proposed research and education activities will accelerate the wide range deployment of ultra-low power wireless networks for environmental and structure monitoring, surveillance, precision agriculture, and biomedical sensing, which can provide early warning to prevent catastrophic results, improve public safety and homeland security, and promote the health and well-being of the general public.
